docs.lead_paragraph: The budget unveiled today by President Clinton shows his extraordinary persistence as an architect of domestic policy. In health care and other social programs, he is pursuing many of the same goals as in 1993, though often by different means. Mr. Clinton is still trying to increase health insurance coverage, still trying to expand eligibility for food stamps, still trying to increase the earned-income tax credit, one of the nation's biggest anti-poverty programs.

headline.main: One Step at a Time, Clinton Seeks More Help for Poor and Elderly
headline.kicker: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: THE GOALS

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton's 2001 fiscal budget shows his extraordinary persistence as an architect of domestic policy; in health care and other social programs, he is pursuing many of same goals as in 1993, though often by different means; new budget offers bigger versions of health care proposals that failed in last few years; asks Congress to spend more money on them, in hope that proposals will prove more popular if they are more generous; health care initiatives discussed; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Republican leaders of the State Senate said today that they intended to pass a bill on Tuesday that for the first time would require health insurance companies to pay for some infertility treatments, edging the Legislature closer to action on the highly contentious issue. The Democrats who control the State Assembly passed a similar bill early last year, only to see it blocked in the Senate amid fierce opposition by some of the Capitol's most influential lobbying groups, including chambers of commerce around the state and the insurance industry.

headline.main: G.O.P. Senate Leaders Back Bill on Insuring Infertility Treatments

docs.abstract: Republican leaders of New York State Senate say that they intend to pass bill that for first time will require health insurance companies to pay for some infertility treatments, edging Legislature closer to action on highly contentious issue (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE REPUBLICANS KEYES RULES OUT McCAIN -- Alan Keyes said yesterday that if Senator John McCain won the Republican presidential nomination he would not support him because, he said, Mr. McCain was not unequivocally opposed to abortion. ''Anyone who votes for John McCain betrays the pro-life call,'' Mr. Keyes said in a speech at the National Press Club in Washington. (NYT) THE POLLS McCAIN GAINS IN CALIFORNIA -- Senator John McCain has cut Gov. George W. Bush's lead in half among California Republicans, according to a poll released yesterday. Less than three weeks ago, Mr. Bush led Mr. McCain by 40 percentage points in the Field Poll. The Field Poll just released shows Mr. Bush ahead 46 percent to 27 percent. It also showed that Vice President Al Gore had slightly widened his lead over former Senator Bill Bradley among Democrats, to a 54 percent to 13 percent advantage, from a 47 percent to 19 percent spread last month. The margin of sampling error was 3.5 to 6 percentage points, depending on voter affiliation. (AP)
